column11: Train severs leg of man crawling between rail cars in Gaslamp - NBC 7 San Diego
column12:
An incident on Monday night is shedding light on a dangerous situation that seems to be happening more near the Gaslamp.

Just after midnight, a man tried to crawl between the cars of a freight train after it had stopped on the tracks near the convention center. As he tried to do so, police say, the train began to move, severing the man's leg below the shin.

Stream San Diego News for free, 24/7, wherever you are with NBC 7. WATCH HERE WATCH HERE

Several videos have gone viral in recent months that show impatient pedestrians climbing on and under trains to get from Harbor Drive to the Gaslamp.

A few months ago, another victim lost her leg at 5th and Harbor while trying to crawl between rail cars.

"These freight trains come through the area," SDPD Lt. Anthony Reese said. "They periodically just stop and pedestrians get a little frustrated not being able to cross because you can't cross while the trains are there stopped, so they take it [upon] themselves just to cross, and, unfortunately, some of them don't make it before the train starts, and they get stuck or they fall and, you know, they succumb to these injuries."

Police are urging people to obey the flashing lights and wait for the train to pass, or to use the pedestrian bridge.

The victim from this latest incident was rushed to the UC San Diego Medical Center. It's not known if surgeons were able to reattach the limb.

San Diego police are handling the investigation.

column11: ME report reveals details about deadly crash between Sprinter train, truck in North County - NBC 7 San Diego
column12:
The San Diego Medical Examiner's office on Thursday released new details about a deadly crash involving a North County Transit District train and a truck in Escondido.

The driver of the pickup truck was identified as 86-year-old Walter Robbins of San Marcos. On Tuesday afternoon, Robbins was attempting to cross the railroad tracks near Enterprise Street at about 1 p.m. when, for unknown reasons, he drove through a lowered automatic gate, the ME report said, citing preliminary information.

Stream San Diego News for free, 24/7, wherever you are with NBC 7. WATCH HERE WATCH HERE

The driver of the gray Toyota then stopped on the train tracks, where the vehicle was struck by an eastbound Sprinter train, the report said. First responders arrived shortly after 911 calls and declared Robbins dead at the scene.

The ME's office found Robbins' cause of death to be blunt force injuries and the manner of death to be an accident.

The San Diego County Sheriff's Department is handling the investigation.

The crash affected rail service along the corridor that stretches east and west from Escondido to Oceanside.

A crash involving a truck and a Metropolitan Transit System trolley left 17 people injured Tuesday and shut down service going both north and south during rush hour in the South Bay.
Three of the patients suffered major trauma in the incident, which took place at around 4:34 p.m. on the Blue Line at Industrial Boulevard and L Street, according to the Chula Vista Fire Department.

Multiple units from Chula Vista and National City responded to the scene, along with MTS crews.

CHULA VISTA, Calif. (FOX 5/KUSI) ‚Äî A collision between a vehicle and a San Diego Metropolitan Transit System trolley injured 17 people Tuesday in Chula Vista, authorities said.

The crash occurred around 4:34 p.m. at Industrial Boulevard and L Street, the Chula Vista Fire Department confirmed to FOX 5/KUSI.

Three of the 17 patients suffered major trauma and were taken to a hospital, according to fire officials. It is unknown if the victims were from the vehicle or trolley.

‚ÄúRiders can use Route 932 for service between the impacted stations. Expect delays on the Blue Line until further notice,‚Äù the MTS said on X, formerly known as Twitter, at 5:04 p.m.

column11: 17 injured after truck collides with trolley at Chula Vista intersection - ABC 10News San Diego
column12:
CHULA VISTA, Calif. (KGTV) ‚Äî Seventeen people were injured Tuesday afternoon Chula Vista Fire officials said after a pickup truck collided with an MTS trolley at an intersection.

Fire officials said the crash happened at approximately 4:30 p.m., at Industrial Boulevard and L Street.

An MTS spokesperson said the truck broadsided a northbound trolley at the L Street grade crossing. One person inside the truck was injured, according to the Chula Vista Police Department.

"Currently there is no Trolley service between H Street Trolley Station and the Iris Avenue Transit Center," a statement from MTS said. "MTS is providing bus shuttles to serve impacted stations between H St. and Iris."

"MTS is investigating the incident and will provide further details when the investigation is complete," the statement said.

column11: Woman Seriously Injured By Train While Trying to Cross Tracks Downtown - Times of San Diego
column12:
Law enforcement at the scene of a train-related injury, Oct. 14 2024. Courtesy Onscene.Media

At least one person was struck and injured in downtown San Diego Monday night when a group of people tried to cross the tracks.

According to police, a group of people became impatient after a train was sitting on the tracks and blocking access to 5th Avenue across the street from the Convention Center and decided to climb over and under the train.

‚ÄúThe trolley arms were down, it was a slow moving train and people‚Ä¶ didn‚Äôt want to wait for the train,‚Äù San Diego police Lt. Anthony Reese told Onscene.Media.

The engineer had no idea that the BNS&F train had struck anybody and thus did not stop, he said. First responders found one person on the tracks.

‚ÄúOne female tried to cross and either got slipped and fell or got stuck underneath the train, and her right leg got run over,‚Äù Reese said, adding that her leg may have to be amputated.

He said that the incident highlights the danger of being around moving trains ‚Äî even slow ones.

column11: First-responders make grisly discovery after female hit by train in Gaslamp Quarter - NBC 7 San Diego
column12:
It's no secret that EMT's and paramedics have one of the toughest jobs out there, but even for them, some days are worse than others.

When an ambulance called out to Harbor Drive and 5th Avenue pulled up last night a little after 10 p.m., the first-responders knew somebody or some people had been hit by a train.

Stream San Diego News for free, 24/7, wherever you are with NBC 7. WATCH HERE WATCH HERE

Very quickly, they discovered that there was only one female victim, and her leg had been badly injured when the train ran over her. The original reporting party had told 911 operators that five people had been injured, but that report was wrong.

Police told NBC 7 on Monday night that the victim had no ID on her when she was struck by the train.

Traffic was shut down in the area while investigators worked the scene. The victim survived her injury and was taken to a local hospital. Her current condition is unknown.

column11: BNSF Railway confirms train involved in incident that ended in woman's leg amputation downtown - ABC 10News San Diego
column12:
SAN DIEGO (KGTV) ‚Äî BNSF Railway confirmed one of their trains was involved in an incident in downtown San Diego Monday night that ended with a woman's leg amputated.

The incident happened on East Harbor Drive near the convention center as people left the Rady Shell after a concert.

San Diego police say a woman and several others were trying to crawl around a stopped train when the train moved, causing several people to fall.

The woman fell under the train and was run over, and her leg had to be amputated.

RELATED: Police: Woman loses leg after being run over by freight train in downtown San Diego

BNSF Railway says the incident is currently under investigation.

1/1 Skip Ad Continue watching after the ad Visit Advertiser website GO TO PAGE

On Tuesday, people who work downtown told ABC 10News that they regularly see the freight trains blocking intersections and crosswalks.

They say people get impatient and start crawling through the train cars or going around them.

"I see people running through that all the time, I see people going around, so if the train is almost to the end to go around it, they'll go around it, I see. People jumping through sometimes, on bikes sometimes like quickly going around it," said Rhiawna Samudio, who works nearby.

Pedicab drivers in the area say they see the same issue with people climbing on and through the trains when they're stationary.

"It takes about 20 to 25 minutes, sometimes even longer, so people get desperate, and they start crossing the train," said Maycl Soto, a pedicab driver who regularly works downtown.

The woman involved in Monday's incident hasn't been identified.

column12: Pedestrian struck, killed by Coaster train in EncinitasENCINITAS ‚Äî A person was fatally struck by a Coaster train on Monday night in Encinitas, the San Diego County Sheriff‚Äôs Department confirmed.While law enforcement confirmed the death, it did not release any additional information concerning the incident.At approximately 6:10 p.m. on Sept. 2, sheriff‚Äôs deputies and fire personnel responded to a train-pedestrian collision in the 2000 block of San Elijo Avenue, according to News Flash Media.Upon arrival at the scene, first responders reportedly discovered a stopped Coaster train and a pedestrian on the railroad tracks. column11: Teen hit, killed by train in Sorrento Valley identified as Torrey Pines High student - NBC 7 San Diego
column12:
A teenager who died after being struck by a train in Sorrento Valley on Friday has been identified by his family.

NBC 7 spoke with the uncle of the teenager who identified the teen as Alex Segal and said they buried him this past weekend.

Stream San Diego News for free, 24/7, wherever you are with NBC 7. WATCH HERE WATCH HERE

The fatal incident occurred last Friday when Segal, on a bicycle, crossed the train tracks and was struck by an oncoming train.

‚ÄúAfter the northbound train passed through, a 17-year-old boy crossed the tracks on his bike, not realizing there was also a passing southbound train,‚Äù the San Diego County Sheriff‚Äôs Department said.

The two other teens were not hurt.

Alex attended Torrey Pines High School and according to the school's website, was a member of the boy's junior varsity soccer team.

In an email to Torrey Pines families, principal Rob Coppo said:

‚ÄúI know we are all deeply saddened by this loss, and we send our condolences to the student‚Äôs family and friends. As you can imagine, the family involved in this tragic accident is going through an extremely difficult time right now. The family is asking that we respect their privacy at this time.‚Äù

"Bike and ebike accidents specifically cause some of the most common injuries Rady Children‚Äôs Hospital treats in the summer, said Matt Derkrikorian a Trauma Program Manager at Rady Children‚Äôs Hospital.

‚ÄúThe state of California has the highest fatalities in the United States,‚Äù said Nancy Sheehan-McCulloch an executive director with the California Operation Lifesaver.

McCulloch says this applies to everything from trespassing on the tracks to people crossing before it‚Äôs safe.

A memorial has been placed to honor the 17-year-old.

column11: Update: 17-year old boy killed by San Diego Amtrak train after riding around crossing gates; 2nd SoCal bike death Friday - BikinginLA
column12:
Sadly, there was more bad news for the Southern California bicycling community on Friday.
According to multiple reports, a 17-year old boy was killed¬†when he was struck by an Amtrak train in San Diego‚Äôs University City neighborhood early Friday afternoon.
The victim, who has not been publicly identified, was crossing the railroad tracks on Sorrento Valley Blvd, between Sorrento Valley Road and Roselle Street, when he was hit by the southbound Amtrak Pacific Surfliner at 12:34 pm.
He died at the scene.
The victim was one of three boys who stopped their bikes at the railroad crossing gates to wait for a northbound train to pass. But as so often happens, he rode around the gates after that train had passed, not realizing another train was coming in the opposite direction.
Tragically, Fox5 reports that the victim‚Äôs parents arrived shortly after the crash, while officials were still removing his mangled bike from the tracks.
The other two boys were not injured. It‚Äôs not clear if they were riding with the victim, or just happened to stop together at the gates.
This is yet another tragic reminder to always wait until the gates go up to cross any rail tracks, regardless of whether it seems safe at the time.
Anyone with information is urged to call the Sheriff‚Äôs Department‚Äôs non-emergency line at 858/565-5200.
This is at least the 24th bicycling fatality in Southern California this year, and the seventh that I‚Äôm aware of in San Diego County.
Update: The victim has been identified 17-year old Alex Segal. He was a student at Torrey Pines High School in the Del Mar Heights neighborhood, and a member of the junior varsity soccer team.
My deepest sympathy and prayers for Alex Segal and all his family and loved ones.
Thanks to Phillip Young for the heads-up.¬†

About 5:30, the San Diego Sheriff's Department released the following information about how the boy was killed:

column11: Woman hit and killed by train in Encinitas; fourth recent death on local tracks - North Coast Current
column12:
Emergency lights. (Ariel Camilo, FreeImages)

A woman was hit and killed by a train in the Encinitas community of Cardiff on Saturday, Feb. 10, the fourth such fatality along North San Diego County tracks since the start of the year.

The incident happened just before 8 a.m. near the intersection of Chesterfield Drive and San Elijo Avenue, the San Diego County Sheriff‚Äôs Department reported. The unidentified woman was hit and killed by a southbound North County Transit District Coaster train.

There were no further details about the incident. The sheriff‚Äôs North Coastal Station handed the investigation to the department‚Äôs Transit Enforcement Unit, which covers incidents on NCTD routes.

The death is the fourth along coastal railroad tracks since the start of the year. A man was killed when he was struck by a BNSF freight train in Encinitas late Jan. 13. Two days later, on Jan. 15, a man was hit and killed by an Amtrak train in Carlsbad. Then, on Feb. 3, a man was struck and killed by a BNSF freight train on Marine Corps Base Camp Pendleton.

In addition, on Jan. 11 in Sorrento Valley, a man was struck and killed by a Coaster train while walking his dog during the early morning.

The Sheriff‚Äôs Department asks anyone with potential information about Saturday‚Äôs incident in Cardiff to call its non-emergency line at 858-565-5200.

Medics took her to UCSD Medical Center for treatment of life- threatening trauma, the sergeant said. Her name was not released.

The crash halted train service in the area for about two hours.

column11: Pedestrian hit by SUV that was hit by train - cbs8.com
column12:
A southbound Coaster commuter train hit a vehicle Saturday afternoon in Del Mar, causing serious injuries to one victim who was hospitalized, according to officials.

DEL MAR (CBS 8/CNS) - A southbound Coaster commuter train hit a vehicle Saturday afternoon in Del Mar, causing serious injuries to one victim who was hospitalized, according to officials.

 

An SUV containing two people in the area where 15th Street crosses the tracks was hit, according to San Diego County sheriff's officials.

 

A woman driving an SUV was attempting to make a U-turn at the train crossing near Coast Boulevard when the crossing arm came down. When she tried to turn around, she got clipped by the train and hit a pedestrian, trapping the victim under the vehicle, according to San Diego County Sheriff's Lt. Dave Schaller.

The pedestrian suffered major injuries and was transported to Scripps La Jolla for evaluation.

About seven deputies responded to the tracks where the Coaster train came to a stop in the area near Ocean Avenue just before 2:30 p.m., Schaller

said.

 

There were apparently two witnesses to the collision, and deputies requested a Farsi translator to respond to the scene, Schaller said.

 

All train service was halted while deputies conducted their investigation.

column11: Amtrak Train Strikes Box Truck in Mission Hills - NBC 7 San Diego
column12:
San Diego police rushed to Mission Hills Friday morning after an Amtrak Surfliner Train hit a box truck.

The accident was reported just after 9:30 a.m. at Pacific Highway and Washington Street in the uptown San Diego area. The San Diego County Sheriff's Department told NBC 7 no injuries were reported.

Traffic was shut down and diverted in the area, officials said. Amtrak service was temporarily shut down in both directions as well.

Officers from the San Diego Police Department, San Diego Fire-Rescue Department (SDFD) crews and officials from the San Diego Metropolitan Transit System (MTS) all responded to the scene.

The collision caused the box truck to also smash into a fence that runs along the train tracks. The box truck plowed through a cross pole and traffic sign, which wound up wedged between the truck and fence. The truck subsequently struck three other vehicles.

The traffic sign also hit an MTS vehicle parked on the other side of the fence, damaging a window.

NBC 7 spoke with Natalie Fernbaugh, a passenger on the Amtrak train bound for Los Angeles.

She said she was listening to music when, suddenly, the train came to a halt.

‚ÄúIt stopped really abruptly. We were just all kind of confused,‚Äù she explained. "It kind of shook."

Fernbaugh said she and other passengers waited in their seats for 15 minutes or so, until they heard an announcement on the speaker from Amtrak staff. They were notified of the accident, and the subsequent delay of their train trip.

Witness Jasmine Pablo was riding in a car with a friend near the tracks, waiting at a red light behind a line of other cars.

She said it looked like the box truck ‚Äì at the front of the line ‚Äì got stuck on the tracks and the oncoming train was unable to avoid hitting it.

As of noon, officials were still investigating and had not yet released further details of what led to the collision.

column11: Man killed by train in San Diego may have been attempting filmed stunt - The Guardian
column12:
An unidentified man who tried to roll under a freight train in downtown San Diego during what authorities say may have been a videotaped stunt was killed on Thursday when he was struck by the locomotive.

The man, who was between 20 and 30 years old, was cut into pieces by the northbound Burlington Northern Santa Fe freight train, which was travelling about 10mph (16km/h) at the time and was 62 cars long, Detective Ed Macken from San Diego County Sheriff‚Äôs Department said.

‚ÄúHe was be-bopping back and forth and there might have been phones up recording,‚Äù Macken said. ‚ÄúHe was trying to do a manoeuvre to shoot under a train and it didn‚Äôt work.‚Äù

The train finally came to a stop about 35 miles (56km) north of the fatal incident.

Macken said the crossing gates were down and warning lights were flashing when the accident happened.

The death highlighted an ongoing problem with open, very visible and accessible train corridors in San Diego County, Macken said.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve had 22 train suicides and accidents in the last year-and-a-half,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt think this one was a suicide, but they all make a big mess.‚Äù

Passenger and freight trains in both directions were stopped for hours while deputies tried to gather evidence and find witnesses.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre still looking for witnesses,‚Äù Macken said. ‚ÄúWhat we know was he was crouched down, bobbing back and forth and then he went for it. Sixty train cars went by and then he rolled under the last two.‚Äù

column11: Tow truck driver killed by Amtrak train in Cardiff ID‚Äôd - cbs8.com
column12:
An autopsy was pending Sunday on a tow truck driver who was fatally struck by a southbound Amtrak train at a grade crossing in Cardiff.

Example video title will go here for this video

Example video title will go here for this video

To stream CBS 8 on your phone, you need the CBS 8 app.

ENCINITAS (CNS) - Authorities Sunday publicly identified the tow truck driver who was struck and killed by an Amtrak train at a railroad crossing in Cardiff-by-the-Sea.

Shaun William Riddle, 27, was attempting to hook a vehicle stalled at Chesterfield Drive and South Coast Highway 101 to the flatbed tow truck about 2:35 p.m. Saturday, according to the San Diego County Medical Examiner's Office.

Riddle was apparently assisting the owner of a broken-down SUV just west of the tracks, sheriff's officials said.

A southbound Surfliner train approached the intersection and Riddle got back into the truck to move it out of the train's path, but could not do so, the Medical Examiner's Office reported.

The train was traveling at a high rate of speed when it struck the tow truck, which reportedly was between closed crossing arms, authorities said. The rig was demolished.

Riddle died at the scene, the Medical Examiner's Office said.

The southbound train stopped at the Solana Beach station, where several of the 125 passengers aboard were treated for minor injuries. Passengers were transferred to another train or buses, and the tracks were reopened shortly before 5 p.m.

column11: Tow Truck Driver Killed in Train Crash - NBC 7 San Diego
column12:
An Amtrak train collided with a tow truck in Cardiff Saturday afternoon killing the driver of the tow truck, officials confirmed.

 

 The crash happened around 2:35 p.m. at Chesterfield Drive and South Coast Highway 101.

 

 According to Encinitas deputies, the driver of the tow truck had stopped on the railroad tracks to assist a disabled SUV that was stalled just west of the tracks.

 

 A short time later, an Amtrak train approached. The tow truck was unable to move in time and was struck by the train. 

 

 The driver of the tow truck sustained fatal injuries and died at the scene, deputies said.

 

 The crash is under investigation

 

 At 3:35 p.m., North County Transit took to their Twitter page to also confirm the collision, tweeting: "Due to an incident on the tracks involving Amtrak, COASTER may experience a delay."

 

 One local witness said he saw the SUV on the flatbed tow truck, both stalled on the tracks. The witness said the train crossing arm dropped on the SUV and a moment later, the train slammed into the tow truck.

The witness caught the entire crash on tape. The video shows the truck driver‚Äôs door closing and then the truck turning away from the train just moments before the collision.

A witness who works across the street from the train tracks said the sound of the fatal crash was horrific.

‚ÄúIt's somewhere between an explosion and thunder. You know, when metal hits metal it makes a noise unto itself,‚Äù explained witness Thomas Neely.

The white SUV was left in place at the intersection.

Moments after the crash, people nearby tried to help and scrambled to find survivors.

One witness said the driver was ejected from his tow truck and thrown some 100 yards from the crash site. On the witness video, people seemed to cover the body of the victim while waiting for emergency crews to arrive.

‚ÄúAnybody else back there?‚Äù a person searching for survivors at the crash site says on the video.

 

 Another resident who lives near the site of the crash told NBC 7 that the impact from the collision shook his whole house.

 

 It‚Äôs unclear how fast the train was traveling at impact, but the southbound Amtrak train came to a stop about half a mile away from the Chesterfield Drive crossing.

 

 Pieces of the tow truck were strewn around the train tracks for hundreds of yards after the crash, including the flatbed, a wheel and even the massive engine block that landed about 200 yards away.

 

 Numerous workers from the company TOWEX later arrived at the scene. The towing company responds to AAA calls.

 

 The company told NBC 7 it wants to respect the privacy of the victim‚Äôs family, so his name was not released. One source confirmed the man had a wife and young daughter.

The Medical Examiner‚Äôs office will identify the victim at a later time.

 

 Most people nearby were saddened to hear that a man lost his life in the crash on the train tracks, including Neely.

 

 ‚ÄúI'm sorry to hear that a mother lost her son, especially during the holidays. There's never a good time but it's just, it's tragic,‚Äù said Neely.

 

 The two women who drove the SUV were not injured.

 

 Deputies at the scene Saturday evening were preparing to question the train‚Äôs engineer. Train services resumed later in the afternoon.

column11: Family and friends remember tow truck driver killed by train - cbs8.com
column12:
The wife of the tow truck driver killed in a train accident in Cardiff on Saturday is remembering her husband.


SAN DIEGO (CBS 8) - The wife of the tow truck driver killed in a train accident in Cardiff on Saturday is remembering her husband. 



Mayra Riddle spoke to News 8, but did not want to appear on camera. She told us her husband Shaun was the best man in the world and was dedicated to her and their baby daughter. She says Shaun would come home every night in time to feed their daughter and get her ready for bed.  



Shaun's friends are also remembering him as a great man who was always willing to lend a helping hand. 



"He taught me how to work hard and take care of my family the way I'm supposed to take care of a family, so he taught me how to be a man," friend Jonnie Brayall said. 



"He was my best friend. He definitely changed my life for sure and I'm never going to forget him. He's always going to be in my heart forever," friend Russell Frioli said. 



Shaun was hit and killed by an Amtrak train while trying to hook a vehicle stalled on the train tracks. The accident is still under investigation.

column11: Man Killed by Trolley Wore Headphones - NBC 7 San Diego
column12:
The man struck by a trolley and killed along Harbor Boulevard and Schley Street early Thursday was wearing headphones and didn't hear the train's horn, police said.

Officers investigating the death say Christopher Brian Roberts, 29, appeared to have been either on his way to work or just returning from work.

Roberts was found with the earphone wrapped around his neck according to a police spokesperson.

The accident happened directly across from the NASSCO Shipyard but there are several other businesses in the area including restaurants and auto repair shops.

There were no witnesses to the accident but officers said Roberts had to walk around the crossing arm to attempt to cross the tracks.

column11: Two fatalities in separate cases May 7 in Escalon - Escalon Times
column12:
The San Joaquin County Coroner‚Äôs Office on Thursday released the identities of two Escalon residents, losing their lives in separate incidents on Wednesday, May 7.

The first incident was a train vs. pedestrian collision, about 1:45 p.m., near the Highway 120 and McHenry Avenue railroad crossing. The victim was identified as Paul Lopez, 63, of Escalon and authorities said he was struck by an Amtrak train. There was also a freight train in the area, apparently stopped on the tracks, and eyewitnesses said the man appeared to walk around the downed crossing arms to get past the freight train when he was struck. The investigation is continuing, taken over by Amtrak Police.

A couple hours later, just after 4 p.m., an Escalon woman died as a result of injuries sustained when the SUV she was driving collided with a hay squeeze along Highway 120 near Sexton Road. She was identified as Glenda Mancilla Larios, 38, of Escalon. The crash also resulted in major injuries to the driver of the farm equipment ‚Äì with a lengthy extrication required ‚Äì and authorities said there were minor passengers in the SUV who were injured and taken to area hospitals. No information was available on their condition. That accident also remains under investigation, being handled by the CHP.

Assisting with the incidents were Escalon Police, Escalon Community Ambulance and Escalon Fire Department personnel, with additional support from Escalon Public Works and Escalon Unified School District personnel at the train/pedestrian collision.

Look for additional details on these incidents in the May 14 issue of The Times.

						A driver was hit and killed by a train Sunday night south of Lodi.A car was traveling westbound on East Armstrong Road, west of Highway 99, when around 6 p.m. it collided with a Union Pacific train traveling southbound, California Highway Patrol said. The crossing arms did go down and it appears the car's driver attempted to beat the train as it went through the intersection, CHP said. The driver was the only person inside the vehicle and they were pronounced dead at the scene.     The train crew was uninjured, Union Pacific said. Click the video player above to watch other morning headlines from KCRA News 3This story was curated by Hearst's KCRA Alert Desk. See more coverage of top California stories here | Download our app.
					

ARMSTRONG, Calif. ‚Äî A driver was hit and killed by a train Sunday night south of Lodi.A car was traveling westbound on East Armstrong Road, west of Highway 99, when around 6 p.m. it collided with a Union Pacific train traveling southbound, California Highway Patrol said. 
The crossing arms did go down and it appears the car's driver attempted to beat the train as it went through the intersection, CHP said. The driver was the only person inside the vehicle and they were pronounced dead at the scene.     The train crew was uninjured, Union Pacific said. Click the video player above to watch other morning headlines from KCRA News 3This story was curated by Hearst's KCRA Alert Desk.

column11: 2 people hurt after crashing into moving train near Lodi - CBS News
column12:
CBS News Sacramento
Live




SAN JOAQUIN COUNTY ‚Äì Two people suffered major injuries after they drove onto a railroad crossing near Lodi and struck by a train that was passing through.California Highway Patrol says, a little before 12:30 p.m. Tuesday, a vehicle with two people inside drove through the closed arms of a railroad crossing. They then struck the train that was going through. It's unknown why the people drove through the closed arms. Both the driver and passenger were left with major injuries, officers say; no one on the train was hurt. Union Pacific confirmed that it was one of their trains involved in the incident.¬†


Officers are still investigating the incident.¬†

Cecilio  Padilla


Cecilio Padilla is a digital producer for CBS Sacramento and a Sacramento-area native who has been covering Northern California for more than a decade.

column11: Driver killed after collision with train near Tracy - CBS News
column12:
CBS News Sacramento
Live




TRACY - A driver died after officials said he drove through crossing arms and was hit by an oncoming train in the Tracy area on Friday morning.¬†The CHP responded to the collision around 8 a.m. near S. Chrisman Road south of Bates Road.¬†They said 68 passengers were on board an ACE commuter train that was traveling west at about 70 mph and was approaching S. Chrisman Road.¬†At the same time, a 58-year-old man was driving a 2004 Honda SUV north at an unknown speed. CHP officers said the crossing arms were in the down position when the man drove through crossing arms, directly in the path of the train.¬†The train struck the passenger side of the vehicle, causing major damage to the train and SUV.


The Honda driver, a man from Tracy, died at the scene. He has not been identified at this time.¬†Anyone with information is urged to contact the CHP - Tracy office.¬†

Brandon  Downs


Brandon Downs is a digital content producer at CBS Sacramento.

column11: Video shows police officer pulling man in wheelchair off railroad tracks before oncoming train hits - NBC News
column12:
Create your free profile or log in to save this article

Create your free profile or log in to save this article

A California police officer pulled a man out of his wheelchair and to safety on Wednesday, moments before he would have been crushed by an oncoming train, dramatic video of the rescue showed.

Lodi police officer Erika Urrea and Sgt. Steve Maynard were on patrol in their Central Valley community when they spotted the 66-year-old man in his wheelchair, stuck on tracks as crossing guards were coming down and a train approached at 8:44 a.m. PT, officials said.

Urrea was driving and she barely caught sight the prone pedestrian out of the corner of her eye.

"So I happen to kind of look to the side and notice there was a man in a wheelchair, and he seemed to be almost wiggling, like he was stuck," Urrea told "NBC Nightly News" on Thursday.

Press shift question mark to access a list of keyboard shortcuts Keyboard Shortcuts Enabled Disabled Play/Pause SPACE Increase Volume ‚Üë Decrease Volume ‚Üì Seek Forward ‚Üí Seek Backward ‚Üê Captions On/Off c Fullscreen/Exit Fullscreen f Mute/Unmute m Decrease Caption Size - Increase Caption Size + or = Seek % 0-9 Settings Off English Font Color White Font Opacity 100% Font Size 100% Font Family Arial Character Edge None Background Color Black Background Opacity 50% Window Color Black Window Opacity 0% Reset White Black Red Green Blue Yellow Magenta Cyan 100% 75% 50% 25% 200% 175% 150% 125% 100% 75% 50% Arial Courier Georgia Impact Lucida Console Tahoma Times New Roman Trebuchet MS Verdana None Raised Depressed Uniform Drop Shadow White Black Red Green Blue Yellow Magenta Cyan 100% 75% 50% 25% 0% White Black Red Green Blue Yellow Magenta Cyan 100% 75% 50% 25% 0% Live 00:00 01:42 01:42 Officer who saved man with wheelchair from oncoming train speaks out 01:43

Urrea's body camera captured the life-and-death seconds, as she sprinted from her squad car to the pedestrian, stuck on Lodi Avenue.

"Can you get up?" Urrea can be heard frantically asking on the bodycam video.

She unbuckled him, grabbed his torso and pulled him up out of the chair.

"Get up, get up, get up, get up, get up!" Urrea screamed n the video while the Union Pacific train fast approached and she pulled him away.

Urrea and the man fell to ground as the train smashed through his wheelchair feet away.

"I need an ambulance now!" Urrea yelled out, with the sound of the train still speeding past.

Erika Urrea. Lodi police department

As these terrifying seconds unfolded, Urrea said she didn't have enough time to become afraid. But 24 hours later, the veteran police officer admitted the video was hard to watch.

"I was trying to figure out 'OK, where's the train? I don't know how fast the train is going. How much time do I have?' But my goal was, 'I need to get him off the tracks,'" Urrea said.

"Honestly, it seems like I'm watching someone else's video. It's very surreal ... it was scary to watch."

The man was taken to the hospital and he was in stable condition on Thursday.

"As the incident happened very quickly we believe the chair wheel was stuck in the groove between the railroad track and the cement," Lodi police Lt. Michael Manetti said.

The 36-year-old single mom, who has beenon the job for 14 years, said ‚Äî unsurprisingly ‚Äî there's no training for dealing with a speeding train.

"No, nothing this specific at least," Urrea laughed, adding that she'll never forget Wednesday's rescue. "The most memorable ... probably the scariest incident that I've been involved with so far."

The officer's supervisors hailed her quick thinking and decisive action.

‚ÄúWe are very proud of Officer Urrea and her heroic actions," Lodi police Capt. David Griffin said in a statement on Thursday. "Thanks to her awareness and quick action she was able to save the man‚Äôs life at great personal risk to herself. This is another shining example of the brave actions the men and women of law enforcement exhibit every day.‚Äù

The video has been viewed millions of times across the world since Lodi police first published it on their YouTube page late Wednesday afternoon.

Former pro basketball player Rex Chapman, a prolific social media scraper who can make video go viral just by sharing it with his 918,000 followers, posted the clip on Wednesday night. And on his feed alone, it took just 17 hours for Lodi clip to reach a million views.

"Oh. My. God," Chapman wrote, summing up the video's content.

A Sacramento TV news anchor, with just 4,500 followers, also had a million views of the video in about the same time frame as Chapman's post.

Urrea shrugged off being called a hero and insisted anyone in her position would have acted as she did.

"I honestly don't think I did anything special. I know all the people that I work with would have done the same thing," the officer said Thursday.

"I just did what I felt that anybody in my situation would have done and something that I felt like, if that was my family member or friend that was stuck, I would want someone to come out and help."

The San Joaquin County community of Lodi, with a population of 67,000, is about 90 miles northeast of San Francisco and 40 miles south of Sacramento.

The agricultural town was the subject of the 1969 song ‚ÄúLodi,‚Äù by Creedence Clearwater Revival. Today Lodi is a major regional producer of wine grapes, particularly Zinfandel.

column11: Caltrain hits tractor-trailer in Burlingame - San Mateo Daily Journal
column12: A truck transporting cars was hit by a southbound Caltrain at the Broadway intersection in Burlingame Monday afternoon, causing some delays for passengers and car traffic but no injuries.¬†The truck was on the tracks as the train approached the Broadway Caltrain station at 12:35 p.m., Caltrain spokesperson Randol White said.¬†There were about 67 passengers on the train who were able to disembark about 50 minutes after the crash, White said. Caltrain switched to single-tracking, and another southbound train picked the passengers up from the Broadway station soon after. Train delays of half an hour or less continued into the afternoon, he said. Police directed car traffic past the crossing, which was blocked off while it was being cleared.¬†‚ÄúSometimes it can be far worse,‚Äù White said, noting that there were no injuries.¬†Store manager Fabiana Pires was working at Maverick Jack‚Äôs when she thought she had heard something falling in the kitchen. It turned out to be the sound of the train hitting the truck.¬†It looked like the train had struck the back of the truck, which then clipped an SUV, she said. First responders on the scene did not want to comment, though Pires said the driver of the SUV had no injuries but was taken away in an ambulance.¬†‚ÄúIt was a scary scene,‚Äù said John Kevranian, co-owner of Nuts for Candy & Toys on Broadway and president of the Broadway Burlingame Business Improvement District. He heard sirens, and walked to the intersection about 10 minutes after the crash. When he saw the train stopped on the tracks, he thought a car or pedestrian had been hit.¬†‚ÄúThere were ambulances, there were fire trucks, all kinds of emergency people there,‚Äù he said.¬†A crossing arm, the bar that comes down between traffic and the tracks when a train comes by, was damaged. A crew from Caltrain was working on it when the truck pulled away from the crossing and parked around the corner more than an hour after being struck.¬†The Broadway crossing has a reputation for being dangerous. There has been a push for ‚Äúgrade separation,‚Äù turning the crossing into an underpass to let trains pass over traffic instead of through it. The project will cost an estimated $316 million.¬†‚ÄúWe have to get this project funded, we have to start this project as soon as possible,‚Äù Kevranian said. ‚ÄúWe have seen accidents, we have seen death, we have seen catastrophe at this location.‚Äù

by Photo by  Ananda Paulas/Bay City News
A person was struck and killed by a southbound Caltrain just south of the Redwood City station on Tuesday morning, according to Caltrain spokesperson Randol White. 
The incident happened around 9 a.m. at Chestnut Street when a pedestrian was on the tracks for unknown reasons, and train #406 stuck and killed the person, according to White. There were 174 passengers on the scene at the time of the collision, and no other injuries were reported, he said. 
The San Mateo County Sheriff‚Äôs Transit Police Bureau, responsible for patrolling the Caltrain corridor, has taken charge of the investigation. The cause of the collision and the identity of the involved individual remain undetermined. The San Mateo County Coroner‚Äôs Office, which arrived on the scene at 9:42 a.m., will release the identity of the individual at a later time, White said. 
The tracks were reopened at 10:11 a.m.
‚ÄúCaltrain reminds everyone to be safe around train tracks,‚Äù Caltrain said in its final email update.

The Incident
On January 18, 2024, at approximately 11:33 a.m., a harrowing incident unfolded near the Hayward Park station in San Mateo, shaking the local community. A northbound Caltrain, making its routine journey from San Jose to San Francisco, tragically struck an individual. The impact of the collision was immediate and fatal, claiming the life of the person struck by the train. column11: Train nearly kills woman trapped on tracks - Palo Alto Daily Post
column12:
The rear end of this car was sheared off by a Caltrain tonight (Oct. 23) in Menlo Park. Photo by Post reader Stu Soffer.

BY EMILY MIBACH
Daily Post Staff Writer
A woman miraculously survived after her car ‚Äî which was trapped between backed-up traffic and a railroad crossing arm ‚Äî¬†was hit by a 78 mph Caltrain in Menlo Park tonight (Oct. 23), according to Fire Chief Harold Schapelhouman.
The woman, who is in her 30s, was headed west on Ravenswood Avenue at 6:15 p.m. when she stopped on the railroad tracks between Alma Street and El Camino Real. When the crossing lights lit up, indicating a train was on its way, she was stuck. The cars in front of her and behind her wouldn‚Äôt move, even though she was frantically honking her horn.
‚ÄúShe was honking, but there was not a whole lot of room for her to move,‚Äù Schapelhouman said.
Witnesses told firefighters that the train lifted the car off the ground. The car was thrown into the air and landed parallel with the train tracks. The woman was still in the car.
The train was headed south at 78 mph. The train was not damaged and did not stop, according to Schapelhouman.
Remarkably, after the train passed and the car hit the ground, the woman was able to drive the vehicle. She circled back to park in the Caltrain parking lot, saying that something ‚Äúdidn‚Äôt feel right‚Äù when she drove her car ‚Äî only to find out that the back of her car had been sheared off.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs amazing the car was still drivable and she wasn‚Äôt more severely insured or even killed,‚Äù said Battalion Chief Dan Coyle.
The woman was taken to Stanford Hospital after complaining of neck and back pains.
This is not the first time someone has been stuck on the tracks at that location during rush hour. On Feb. 23, 2015, Jahyun Jennifer Koo, 35, of Palo Alto, died when she became trapped between a railroad gate and a car stopped by traffic in front of her.
Her death resulted in a lawsuit against Caltrain, San Mateo County and the city of Menlo Park. The outcome of the lawsuit wasn‚Äôt available tonight.
Koo‚Äôs death also prompted the city to install temporary medians on Ravenswood Avenue from Alma to Noel Drive to prevent left-hand turns onto Ravenswood from Alma Street.
‚ÄúThis at-grade crossing is notorious for many significant near misses and sadly tragic accidents involving the loss of life. It‚Äôs a poorly designed crossing exacerbated by people who are in a hurry and not paying attention that can then suddenly find themselves in harm‚Äôs way,‚Äù said Schapelhouman. ‚ÄúThe train can‚Äôt swerve to avoid an impact and if the Express is coming through it takes about a mile for it to slow down and stop because it‚Äôs going about 80 mph. This should have been improved years ago, but the debate on how to fix this crossing has gone on for decades ‚Ä¶ in the meantime our firefighters continue to directly deal with the very real deadly consequences and close calls associated with it.‚Äù
After decades of squabbling over how to separate the train tracks from the road at Ravenswood, the council decided earlier this year to raise the tracks and lower the road at Ravenswood. It‚Äôs estimated the separation will cost $190 million.

column11: San Bruno Man Killed On CalTrain Tracks, Officials Said. - Patch
column12:
Crime & Safety
San Bruno Man Killed On CalTrain Tracks, Officials Said.
Man throws himself on CalTrain tracks, commits suicide.
The coroner's office identified the man who was struck and killed by a freight train Monday night as Anthony Michael Thimmes, 37. No other information has been determined about him at this point. The coroner is still investigating the cause of the death.
Caltrain confirmed that Thimmes - who was struck and killed by a Union Pacific train near San Mateo Avenue in downtown San Bruno - had apparently intentionally threw himself in front of the train.
Find out what's happening in San Carlosfor free with the latest updates from Patch.
Spokeswoman Christine Dunn said the Union Pacific train that struck Thimmes was on its way to pick up freight cars in Santa Clara. The train was not pulling any freight cars at the time of the accident.
Following the accident, trains were delayed in both directions for about two hours. All tracks were reopened for service at 9:32pm, Dunn said.
Find out what's happening in San Carlosfor free with the latest updates from Patch.
San Bruno resident Jose Romero was walking his dog on Huntington Avenue around 7:50 p.m., a few minutes after the accident occurred, and said he overheard a woman telling emergency crews that she saw a man throw himself in front of the train.
Romero said he didn't realize what had happened until he saw the police cars and fire engines arrive at the scene.
"That's when it all clicked that that's what she was saying," Romero said.
He said there are a lot of homeless people that usually congregate in the area at night.
There have been eight fatalities on Caltrain tracks this year, five of which have been determined to be suicides, Dunn said. Last year there were 19 train-related fatalities. Of those, 15 incidents were found to be suicides and four were accidental.
Suicide prevention signs had recently been installed by CalTrain. The call station is located in San Carlos.

column11: Capitol Corridor Train Slams Into Tesla on Tracks in Santa Clara - NBC Bay Area
column12:
A Capitol Corridor train slammed into a Tesla on the tracks Wednesday morning, injuring the driver in Santa Clara.

The collision reportedly occurred in the 600 block of Martin Avenue in Santa Clara. Video from the scene shows a gray Tesla smashed and airbags deployed.

Watch NBC Bay Area News free wherever you are WATCH HERE WATCH HERE

The driver of the Tesla reportedly tried to beat the train through the crossing, NBC Bay Area learned.

Witnesses told NBC Bay Area the Tesla driver was sitting on the tracks and distracted when the crossing arm came down on the car. She reportedly exited the car, moved the arm off the vehicle then tried to beat the train.

A Capitol Corridor train slammed into a Tesla on the tracks Wednesday morning in Santa Clara.

Police, VTA and work crews showed up to the scene where parts of the car were thrown in all directions.

A passing driver who works near the scene of the incident told NBC Bay Area a large section of the Tesla's drive train actually hit his car.

The driver of that car, Emilio Martinez, is a licensed EMT and was able to help the Tesla driver who sustained minor injuries, police said.

The Capitol Corridor train was delayed as crews checked for damage and fortunately, no passengers were injured.

Witnesses who saw the incident happened are shaken up, but relieved.

"I think we need to be very careful not to try to 'win' the train," a witness told NBC Bay Area. "The train will never stop. We could lose our life like that."

column11: Tesla driver gets minor injuries after train crashes into EV: report - Teslarati
column12:
There are several things that drivers never want to be involved in. A crash with a train is definitely one of them. Fortunately for a driver in Santa Clara, she happened to be inside a Tesla, and she was able to escape the frightening ordeal with minor injuries.¬†



The incident happened on Wednesday morning when a Capitol Corridor train smashed into what appears to be a Midnight Silver Tesla Model Y on the 600 block of Martin Avenue in Santa Clara. Videos taken of the incident‚Äôs aftermath show a crushed Tesla with its airbags deployed.¬†



As noted in a report from¬†NBC Bay Area, the driver of the Tesla reportedly tried to beat the train through the crossing ‚Äî an incredibly dangerous move and one that could have easily claimed a life. According to witnesses interviewed by the news outlet, the Tesla driver was reportedly sitting on the tracks when the crossing arm came down on the vehicle.¬†



The Tesla driver reportedly seemed distracted when the crossing arm hit the electric car. Witnesses were then shocked to see the driver reportedly exit the vehicle to move the arm off the Tesla. The driver then reportedly tried to beat the train but was unsuccessful. The train smashed into the all-electric vehicle, and its parts ended up being thrown in all directions.¬†



Despite the Tesla driver‚Äôs apparent carelessness and recklessness, she was ultimately lucky. One driver, Emilio Martinez, whose vehicle was hit by a large section of the Tesla, was actually a licensed EMT, so he ended up being the first responder on the scene. The Tesla driver didn‚Äôt respond to the EMT at first, though later statements from the police indicated that the EV driver only sustained minor injuries. No passengers from the train were injured during the crash as well.¬†
Ultimately, crashes such as this are among the reasons why Tesla is pushing the development of technologies like Autopilot and Full Self-Driving. Systems like FSD tend to drive conservatively and cautiously, and they do not get distracted. Thus, when solutions such as FSD are fully rolled out, instances of accidents from distracted drivers would likely see a notable decline.¬†



NBC Bay Area‚Äôs report on the Tesla and train‚Äôs crash can be viewed below.¬†

Caltrain spokesperson Dan Lieberman said trains were single-tracking through the affected area until was cleared.

The collision happened at approximately 4:47 p.m., when northbound train No. 253 collided with an individual near West Meadow Drive.

There were approximately 200 passengers on the train at the time of the collision, Lieberman said.

The San Mateo County Sheriff‚Äôs Office‚Äôs Transit Police Bureau is investigating the incident.

As of Wednesday, a staff member with the Santa Clara County Medical Examiner-Coroner‚Äôs Office said the person had not yet been identified.

Help is available

Any person who is feeling depressed, troubled or suicidal can call 800-784-2433 to speak with a crisis counselor. People in Santa Clara County can call 855-278-4204. Spanish speakers can call 888-628-9454.

People can reach trained counselors at Crisis Text Line by texting 741741.

Read more: How to help those in crisis

This story will be updated as more information becomes available.

column11: UPDATE: Man killed at Churchill Avenue rail crossing identified - Palo Alto Daily Post
column12:
By the Daily Post staff

FRIDAY, JAN. 20, 3:30 p.m.: The man killed by a train at the Churchill Avenue Caltrain crossing yesterday has been identified by the Santa Clara County Medical Examiner-Corner as Gary Zweig, 71.

THURSDAY, JAN. 21, 4:10 p.m.: The Churchill Avenue Caltrain crossing this afternoon after a train hit and killed a man on the tracks.

The collision occurred around 3:40 p.m. The train was No. 261 headed toward San Francisco. It had 22 passengers on board.

Palo Alto police advise motorists to expect delays in the area, and to take alternate routes to avoid traffic congestion.

All trains are stopped in the area as of shortly after 4 p.m.

The fatality is the first on Caltrain‚Äôs right-of-way in 2021.

The Transit Police Bureau of the San Mateo County Sheriff‚Äôs Office investigates all collisions on the railroad corridor.

Caltrain is saying the person killed was a ‚Äútrespasser‚Äù but the circumstances of the fatal crash haven‚Äôt been determined. The man hasn‚Äôt been identified publicly.

column11: Person Struck, Killed by Caltrain in Sunnyvale - NBC Bay Area
column12:
A northbound Caltrain struck and killed a person on the tracks north of the Sunnyvale station Monday morning, a spokeswoman for the transit agency said.

Northbound train No. 305, traveling from San Jose to San Francisco, struck the person around 6 a.m., Caltrain spokeswoman Tasha Bartholomew said.

None of the 170 passengers aboard the train were injured. All trains stopped in the area after the collision, and the southbound tracks reopened for trains at reduced speeds by 7 a.m.

As of shortly after 8:30 a.m., the tracks in both directions reopened for trains at maximum speeds, Bartholomew said.

The San Mateo County sheriff's Transit Police Bureau, which patrols the Caltrain corridor, is investigating the fatality. Bartholomew said it is too early for investigators to determine whether the death was intentional or accidental.

The name of the victim will be released by the Santa Clara County medical examiner's office.

column11: 14-year-old struck by VTA train in San Jose fighting for her life - KTVU
column12:
14-year-old struck by VTA train in San Jose fighting for her life
SAN JOSE, Calif. (KTVU) - The family of a teenage San Jose girl hit and critically injured by a VTA light rail train on Wednesday is asking for the public‚Äôs help determining how the accident happened.
Family members say Michelle Espinoza is an effervescent 14-year-old with an infectious personality. She remains at Valley Medical Center where she is fighting for her life.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard. We can‚Äôt believe this happened. We wanna know how it happened,‚Äù said Liliana Rosas, the girl‚Äôs aunt.
Rosas and other family members sat outside the hospital Friday morning, trying to make sense of it all.
Espinoza clings to life in critical condition, with a fractured skull, swelling of the brain, broken ribs and clavicle, and other injuries.
Late Wednesday morning, Espinoza was riding her bike near Southwest Expressway and Stokes Street. She was hit by a VTA light rail train as it made its way through the intersection.
‚ÄúAll we know is that we‚Äôre thankful she‚Äôs alive and she‚Äôs fighting. She‚Äôs very strong,‚Äù said Eliana Espinoza, Michelle‚Äôs older sister.
San Jose police say the teen was riding her bike east on Stokes Street and went around the crossing barriers, which were functioning. She peddled across the tracks, but there‚Äôs no explanation as to how or why she was hit by the southbound train. VTA officials stress being situationally aware when near or using their system.
‚ÄúOften times, you may not see or hear a bus coming. So it‚Äôs important you look both directions," said Holly Perez, a VTA spokeswoman. "Remove the distractions like earbuds, and really follow the directional signs. Whether it‚Äôs lights, directional signs or crossing gates."
After Espinoza was struck, family member say a Good Samaritan pulled her off the tracks and administered CPR.
In the family's search for answers to the accident, they want to personally thank the stranger who may have helped save a 14-year-old‚Äôs life.
‚ÄúWe would love for the person who helped her to come forward. And we would like to meet them, and thank them and just give them a big hug,‚Äù said Eliana Espinoza.
The Espinoza family set up a ‚ÄúGoFundMe‚Äù page for Michelle, to help with costs associated with her medical bills. To donate click here.

column11: San Jose police say driver went around crossing gates in VTA, car crash that killed 2 - ABC7 San Francisco
column12:
SJPD says driver went around crossing gates in VTA, car crash that killed 2

Two people died in a crash with a VTA train in San Jose Sunday afternoon, according to VTA officials.

Two people died in a crash with a VTA train in San Jose Sunday afternoon, according to VTA officials.

Two people died in a crash with a VTA train in San Jose Sunday afternoon, according to VTA officials.

Two people died in a crash with a VTA train in San Jose Sunday afternoon, according to VTA officials.

SAN JOSE, Calif. (KGO) -- Security video from Hapa's Brewery shows customers outside enjoying their beer when all of a sudden a vehicle collides with a VTA train. The car, a gold Buick Regal, is mangled, while the train runs off its rails.

"The corner of my eye just happen to see this dude turning right when the train came and hit him and for a half a second my brain didn't register what it was and then you heard the loudest sound you've ever heard," said witness Ryan Stern.

The train operator and the roughly 20 passengers on board suffered no serious injuries. Passenger Jose Zarate is recovering from a sore hand.

"It felt like a tin can just crunching. You see the walls coming down on you. You don't know what to expect you know? I didn't know if it was a bomb. I didn't know what it was. I didn't know it was a car until after," said Zarate.

The male driver of the Buick and his male passenger died at the scene. Witnesses say they may have been living out of their car. They say it was packed with possessions.

RELATED: Deadly crash prompts delays on VTA in San Jose

"We all went out to the car and the dude was barely breathing and people were telling him to stay with him but it's pretty hard to survive a wreck like that," said Stern.

San Jose Police say the crossing arms were down and functioning, but the man behind the wheel still tried to drive around them. Investigators say the Buick was going south while the Mountain View to Winchester VTA train was heading north.

"We're just encouraging everyone that safety is really everyone's job so whether you're a pedestrian, driving a vehicle or a bicyclist, we all need to exhibit caution with the crossing gates, signs and platforms," said VTA Spokesperson Holly Perez.

Currently, a bus bridge is transporting passengers between stations. Service disruptions will likely continue for the next day or so. VTA says passengers should check their website and Twitter feed for service updates.

The crash is under investigation.

column11: UPDATE: Woman Killed in Caltrain Accident Identified - Patch
column12:
Crime & Safety
UPDATE: Woman Killed in Caltrain Accident Identified
Woman was with her husband visiting family.
The Santa Clara County medical examiner's office has identified the woman killed when the car she was driving was struck by a Caltrain in Palo Alto on Friday as Judith Goldblatt.
Northbound train No. 369 struck Goldblatt's Nissan Altima rental car at Charleston Road near Alma Street at about 5 p.m. Friday, Caltrain spokeswoman Tasha Bartholomew said.
None of the 300-400 passengers aboard the train was injured.
Find out what's happening in Palo Altofor free with the latest updates from Patch.
Goldblatt, a 65-year-old resident of Indianapolis, IN, and her husband were visiting family in Palo Alto. Her husband managed to get out of the car.
San Mateo County Transit Police, a branch of the sheriff's office, did not know whether Goldblatt had attempted to escape from the car, Bartholomew said.
Find out what's happening in Palo Altofor free with the latest updates from Patch.
Caltrain service was halted in both directions after the accident, but resumed shortly before 8 p.m.

column11: Crash with Train Injures Motorist, 63, on Old Chittenden Rd near Hwy 129 in Santa Cruz County - The Legal Examiner
column12:
Santa Cruz County, CA ‚Äî A collision between a train and a car on Monday afternoon, June 17, 2024, has left a woman with minor injuries, according to KSBW.
California Highway Patrol (CHP) officials stated that the crash occurred around 1:45 PM on Old Chittenden Road near Highway 129. A 63-year-old woman from Watsonville driving a white Honda Fit was traveling north on a private road close to Old Chittenden Road. Simultaneously, a train was heading west on the tracks just ahead of her vehicle.
For reasons yet to be determined, the car and the train collided. Fortunately, the driver sustained only minor injuries and was promptly taken to a nearby hospital by ambulance for medical evaluation and treatment. None of the passengers or crew members on the train were injured in the crash.
The CHP is actively investigating the cause of the accident. Preliminary assessments indicate that drugs and alcohol do not appear to be contributing factors.
Personal Injury Claims
Determining fault in a collision can hinge on various factors, and in California, partial liability can be assigned to multiple parties. Assisting in establishing legal liability is one of the key roles that a personal injury attorney can fulfill for victims recovering from a traffic accident.
Suppose it is determined that the actions of another contributed toward the injuries. In that case, victims may qualify to file a personal injury claim with the insurance provider of those responsible. Such a claim can offer compensation to help offset hospital expenses, burial costs, and the loss of income from taking time off work for recovery.
Martin Gasparian is the founder of Maison Law, a California Personal Injury Law Firm. Martin is a graduate of Georgetown University Law School and has been practicing law in California 2004. His practice focuses on helping injury victims know their rights and recover just compensation.

column11: Updated: Fatal Amtrak train vs. vehicle accident - KTVL
column12:
[UPDATE: 1:07 PM]

The report of a crash between a car and an Amtrak train came in just before 8:30 a.m. Tuesday.

After a preliminary investigation, the Siskiyou County Sheriff's Office has released a statement, noting that the "a vehicle, operated by a driver allegedly observed driving at a high-rate of speed prior to the collision, was southbound on US 97 when the vehicle ran through the crossing gate and collided with the train‚Äôs engine."

The car had caught fire after the initial impact from the crash. The driver was pronounced dead at the scene. A dog was also found in the car after fire department personnel put out the flames. Authorities are withholding the man's identity until next of kin can be notified.



SCSO adds that all railroad crossing arm barriers and signals were working at the time of the incident.

The railway crossing is located just north of Railroad Ave, at US Hwy 97 in Dorris, California.

There are no injuries to the approximately 210 passengers or crew members on board and the train has been delayed for approximately 25 minutes. Amtrak Police are cooperating with local law enforcement to investigate the incident.

The train hit the car within Dorris city limits.

There are no injuries to the passengers on the train.

column11: Suisun City Train Collision Kills Pedestrian - sacramentoinjuryattorneysblog.com
column12:
Suisun City Train Collision Kills Pedestrian
Pedestrian Killed in Suisun City Train Collision Near Main Street
A Suisun City train collision on the Capitol Corridor route caused significant service disruptions on the evening of May 7. According to the Amtrak train status map, train 540, heading toward Sacramento, was halted just east of the Suisun-Fairfield station due to a service disruption on the tracks when a pedestrian was struck and killed.
Passengers Switched to Alternative Following Suisun City Train Collision
Capitol Corridor spokespersons reported shortly before 7:30 p.m. that arrangements were being made for passengers on Train 540 to transfer to an alternative train in Suisun City. The disruption follows an ongoing investigation at the collision scene, and exact details remain unclear. The Suisun City Police Department confirmed they are investigating the incident involving the death and noted that they will provide more information as it becomes available.
Railway Negligence and Legal Responsibility
Railway companies must follow regulations and perform routine maintenance to ensure the safety of vehicles, bicyclists, and pedestrians who may cross their tracks. Failure to fulfill this responsibility can lead to a Suisun City train collision that results in property damage, severe injuries, or even fatalities. Instances of railway negligence can create grounds for holding railroad companies accountable in the event of a train collision with another vehicle.
- Safety: Railroads and their employees are responsible for adhering to all safety regulations when operating on the tracks. Taking safety precautions at railroad crossings is vital, and railroads can be held liable for any damages or injuries caused by employees who fail to follow these standards.
- Maintenance and Repair: Proper maintenance of tracks and crossings is essential to prevent accidents such as derailments and collisions. Rail companies may be held responsible for damages resulting from train collisions if they neglect to maintain their infrastructure.
- Train Collisions Involving Pedestrians and Vehicles: To ensure safety, it is crucial for railroads to properly maintain crossings and tracks, as well as for individuals to exercise caution when crossing railroad intersections to avoid a Suisun City train collision. Failure by the owner of the tracks and crossings to do so can result in liability for the railroad company in case of accidents or injuries.
Seeking Justice After a Fatal Train Accident
Losing a loved one in a train collision is a devastating experience, and it is crucial to seek legal assistance promptly to ensure accountability for the damages. Consulting with a personal injury attorney can provide valuable guidance and help protect your rights. To recover financial losses and secure compensation for the emotional and psychological impact, families may consider filing a wrongful death claim.
Attorney Ed Smith shares insights to help you better understand wrongful death claims below:
Train Accident Wrongful Death Lawyers
I‚Äôm Ed Smith, a Fairfield wrongful death lawyer. If you have lost a loved one in a Suisun City train collision, our team of compassionate attorneys is here to help. We offer free and friendly advice to guide you through this difficult time. You can contact us at (916) 921-6400 or (800) 404-5400, or reach out to us online. We can provide a no-obligation case review, answer your questions, and discuss whether your family may pursue a wrongful death lawsuit to seek compensation for your loss.
Why Choose Our Injury Lawyers
Our injury lawyers have a proven track record of helping clients secure fair compensation for their cases. You can learn more about our achievements by exploring the following resources: Settlements and Verdicts, Yelp, and Avvo. These links provide insight into the dedication and results our team consistently delivers for clients.
We are also honored to be members of prestigious legal associations that highlight our commitment to excellence. These memberships include Top 1 Percent and Million Dollar Advocates. Being part of these organizations motivates us to maintain the highest quality of service and achieve the best outcomes for those we represent.

column11: Pedestrian killed by train on Capitol Corridor route in Suisun City - CBS News
column12:
CBS News Sacramento
Live




SUISUN CITY ‚Äî Suisun City police said a pedestrian was hit and killed by a train Wednesday evening.The collision with the pedestrian happened in the area of Sunset and Railroad avenues.The Intercity Rail Map, which shows the status of Amtrak trains, shows Train 540 on the Capitol Corridor route heading from Oakland to Sacramento was stopped due to a service disruption, just east of the Suisun-Fairfield station.Amtrak said Thursday that the collision happened around 5:50 p.m. and involved "an individual who was trespassing on the tracks."Solano County officials have identified the individual as 46-year-old Suisun City resident Jacqueline Roofner.


A spokesperson for the Capitol Corridor service said arrangements were made for passengers of the 540 train to transfer to a different train.Suisun City police said they would release more details when they are available.

MOLLY IS STANDING BY THERE WITH THE CROWDS. THOUSANDS WHO PACKED IN FOR A VIEW OF A LARGE JUMBOTRON THERE IN FRONT OF THE BASILICA, SHOWING FOCUS ON THAT CHIMNEY. MOLLY. LESTER. VATICAN NEWS TELLS US THAT ABOUT 30,000 PEOPLE WERE HERE. I‚ÄôVE GOT TO SAY, AFTER THAT NEWS CAME OUT, IT LOOKED LIKE PEOPLE WERE STILL STREAMING IN. SO NOW YOU CAN SEE EVERYONE‚ÄôS LEAVING. IT WAS ABSOLUTELY PACKED. AND BEING HERE JUST ABOUT A WEEK AND A HALF AGO, WITH ABOUT 250,000 PEOPLE, THERE WAS STILL ROOM TO MOVE AROUND AND THERE WAS A LOT OF JOY. EVERYONE WAS VERY RESPECTFUL TONIGHT. AND AGAIN, WE SPOKE ABOUT THIS EARLIER, LESTER. BUT THIS KIND OF COMMUNAL ATMOSPHERE, THOUGH, FOR TOURISTS WHO WERE JUST CURIOUS, WHO HAPPENED TO BE ON VACATION FOR PEOPLE THAT FLEW DIRECTLY OVER FOR THIS, FOR PEOPLE THAT LIVE HERE IN ROME WHO KIND OF HEARD EARLIER THE ANNOUNCEMENTS, HEARD THE SINGING COMING OUT FROM THESE JUMBOTRONS AND WERE CALLED TO THE SQUARE. IT WAS THIS UNBELIEVABLE EXPERIENCE TO BE OUT HERE, VERY DIVERSE, LOTS OF DIFFERENT LANGUAGES, LOTS OF DIFFERENT FLAGS THAT WE STARTED TO SEE. LESTER. AND WE ARE KEEPING OUR EYES OUT, OF COURSE, FOR LITTLE POCKETS, KIND OF NATIONAL POCKETS POPPING UP WITH FLAGS. PEOPLE WERE CHANTING. THE OTHER THING WE NOTICED TONIGHT IS THAT OCCASIONALLY SOMEONE WOULD GET EXCITED SOMEWHERE IN THE CROWD, AND SOME APPLAUSE WOULD BREAK OUT, OR SOMEONE WOULD POINT AT THE CHIMNEY OR IN THE DIRECTION OF THE CHIMNEY, AND IT MIGHT HAVE JUST BEEN A BIRD, BUT PEOPLE WERE GETTING JUMPY BY THE KIND OF THREE HOUR MARK. LESTER. YEAH, WAITING. I THINK WE WERE ALL A BIT CURIOUS AS TO WHAT‚ÄôS TAKING THEM SO LONG. WE‚ÄôLL PROBABLY NEVER HAVE THE ANSWER TO THAT QUESTION, BUT I THINK IT WAS WIDELY SHARED AROUND HERE, ESPECIALLY AS THE EVENING GROWS COOL AND A LITTLE LESS COMFORTABLE TODAY. MOLLY, THANKS VERY MUCH. AND AND AS WE LOOK AHEAD TO TOMORROW, REMIND US HOW THIS WORKS, THEY‚ÄôLL TAKE A TOTAL OF FOUR VOTES TOMORROW. THERE‚ÄôLL BE TWO BALLOTS IN THE MORNING. AND IF THERE IS NO POPE ELECTED ON THE FIRST BALLOT IN THE MORNING, THEY WON‚ÄôT BURN THAT UNTIL THE SECOND BALLOT HAPPENS. AND THEN THEY‚ÄôLL BURN BOTH OF THOSE TOGETHER. AND THEN THE SAME PROCESS HAPPENS IN THE AFTERNOON. AND THEN IF WE GET TO SUNDAY AND THERE IS NO ONE SELECTED. THINGS. THERE‚ÄôS A PAUSE. THERE‚ÄôS A DAY OFF FROM VOTING. THE SENIOR CARDINAL DEACON, WHO‚ÄôS CARDINAL DOMINIQUE MAMBERTI, WOULD GIVE AND WOULD ADDRESS THE WHOLE GROUP. THERE WOULD BE A WHOLE DAY FOR PEOPLE TO TALK TO EACH OTHER AND SEE WHAT THEY WANT TO DO, AND THEN THEY‚ÄôD PICK UP THE VOTING AGAIN ON MONDAY. BUT WE HAVEN‚ÄôT GOTTEN THERE IN PREVIOUS NO REASON. NO. AND I, I THINK IT WOULD BE EXCEPTIONAL IF WE GOT THERE THIS TIME. ALL RIGHT. WELL, THANKS TO ALL OF YOU FOR WAITING IT OUT WITH US HERE AS WE CONTINUE TO WATCH. SO THAT CONCLUDES THIS NBC NEWS SPECIAL REPORT ON THE FIRST DAY OF THIS PAPAL CONCLAVE. WE‚ÄôLL HAVE MUCH MORE AHEAD ON OUR STREAMING NETWORK, NBC NEWS, NOW ONLINE AT NBC NEWS.COM. AND A FULL WRAP UP TONIGHT ON NBC NIGHTLY NEWS. I‚ÄôM LESTER HOLT IN ROME. THANK YOU FOR WATCHING AND GOOD DAY. AND THAT WAS AN NBC NEWS SPECIAL REPORT. ONE LAST LIVE LOOK, VATICAN CITY, AND YOU CAN SEE SAINT PETER‚ÄôS SQUARE THERE. ALL THE PEOPLE THAT WERE GATHERED WAITING TO SEE WHAT WOULD HAPPEN WITH THE CHIMNEY. WE DID SEE BLACK SMOKE COMING FROM THE CHIMNEY. AND THAT SIGNALED A VOTE HAD BEEN MADE. NO POPE WAS ELECTED. THAT WAS ABOUT AFTER THREE HOURS OF WAITING. AND WHEN THE DECISION IS OFFICIALLY MADE, WE WILL KNOW THAT THE NEW POPE HAS BEEN SELECTED BECAUSE WE WILL SEE WHITE SMO

column11: Fairfield Amtrak Train Collision Causes Fatality and Injuries - sacramentoinjuryattorneysblog.com
column12:
Fatality and Injuries Occur in Amtrak Train Collision at East Tabor Avenue

An Amtrak train collision occurred with a motor vehicle in Fairfield on April 26, resulting in one fatality and injuries. The accident happened at about 8:39 a.m. at the East Tabor and Railroad Avenues crossing. Authorities with the Fairfield Fire Department reported that the vehicle that was struck by the train initially hit another car, resulting in major damage.

Investigation Underway to Determine Cause of Train Collision

One person died in the collision, while several others suffered major to moderate injuries and were transported to trauma centers for treatment. The accident is being investigated to determine fault and how it occurred.

Negligent Railroads Can Cause Motor Vehicle Collisions

When operating on tracks, railroads are required to obey regulations and perform regular maintenance to protect vehicles, bicyclists, and pedestrians that may cross. Upon failing to do this, they may cause serious accidents that can damage property, cause injury and even result in death. Railway negligence can result in several ways of holding railroads responsible in a train crash with another vehicle:

Equipment defects: Railroads are responsible for ensuring their equipment, such as brakes, tracks, couplings and engines, are in proper working order. Railroads can be liable for train crashes caused by defective equipment if they fail to perform maintenance or use old, outdated machinery or parts.

Track maintenance resulting in negligence: Railroads are responsible for properly maintaining tracks to ensure they are free of debris or other hazards that might cause an oncoming train to collide. In addition, worn tracks can lead to a train collision or derailment, so maintenance and repair are especially important. Rail companies can be held liable for damages resulting from train-vehicle collisions if they fail to maintain their tracks and crossings properly.

Safety: Taking safety precautions when passing through railroad crossings and following all safety regulations is the responsibility of railroads and their employees when operating on the tracks. Railroads are liable for damages or injuries caused by employees who fail to do so.

Wrongful Death Claims After a Train Accident

In the event of the death of a loved one in a train collision, you should seek legal help as soon as possible so everyone is held accountable for the damages. Your case can be evaluated by a personal injury attorney who will fight for your rights. To recover financial losses and receive compensation for emotional and psychological trauma, the family may wish to file a wrongful death claim.

If an accident attorney determines that negligence by the railway company or others was the cause of death, the family of a deceased loved one can file a wrongful death claim. A person or entity must be proven to have caused the untimely death through negligence. It is possible for the estate administrator or members of the immediate family to file a claim. However, only one claim may be filed. If you would like more information, please do not hesitate to contact our office.

Amtrak Train Accident Lawyer

I am Ed Smith. I‚Äôm an Amtrak train accident lawyer. You may benefit from our free and friendly advice if you have lost a loved one or someone in your family has been injured in a train crash. If you have questions, please call us at (916) 921-6400 or (800) 404-5400. Additionally, you can reach us online.

See how our injury lawyers got fair compensation for our clients by clicking the links below:

column11: Amtrak train, vehicle involved in crash in Fairfield; 1 dead, several people hurt - CBS News
column12:
Amtrak train, vehicle involved in crash in Fairfield; several people hurt 






















Amtrak train, vehicle involved in crash in Fairfield; several people hurt
00:23




FAIRFIELD ‚Äì One person was killed after a crash involving a vehicle and a train in Fairfield on Wednesday morning.¬†The scene is near E. Tabor and Railroad avenues.An eastbound Amtrak train struck a vehicle near the intersection, Fairfield Fire says. The vehicle suffered major damage -- with the ricochet sending it into a second vehicle.¬†Several people were taken to the hospital with injuries ranging from moderate to major, firefighters say. One person has died from their injuries, Fairfield police said.¬†About 120 people, including passengers and crew, were on board the train but no injuries were reported to them.


Due to the crash, E. Tabor Avenue was closed between Clay Bank and Tolenas roads. Officials had reopened the road by early Wednesday afternoon.¬†The name of the person killed has not been released.¬†
